Again, while disagreeing with Ignatios on guns, I find much common ground with him on big-picture solutions.

Ignatios, I feel that if folks like us were ever able to sit down at a table with a chance to outline workable policies, we could find many fundamental areas of agreement.

Ignatios and I disagree on much when it comes to guns, but his point here is valid. He and I are unlikely to be victims of a home invasion. The paranoia of those who claim "evil shows up uninvited" ignores that the majority of the victims out there know their killers.

As Ignatios hints at, the signifiers of gun violence are pretty clear, and while it may be easy to make assumptions about race because gun violence impacts African Americans more than Whites, non-racial factors work for anyone - previous violent offenses, lower education levels, substance abuse issues, any previous arrests.

It would be so easy to create barriers that make it harder for folks like these to get guns - not impossible, but much, much harder.

And that alone would save so many lives.

So you want a "mob of gang-bangers" to be able to buy machine guns at 7-11s?

You said "un-infringed." Legalize land mines? Shoulder-fired missiles?

Do you think murderers on parole should be legally able to buy guns? That's un-infringed.

Do you think 5th graders should be able to bring firearms to school?

What about those adjudged mentally ill? An AK-47 for every schizophrenic?

How about vets with PTSD issues? Chris Kyle thought it was a good idea to offer to take them shooting...as therapy. How did that work out?

Do you really think about words like "un-infringed" before you write them?

Hard to see if you are being sarcastic or sincere.

Of course you know that your odds of dying from a gunshot rise dramatically if you own a gun. They rise much more if you have a concealed weapons permit.

To say that "to not help an enemy" is correct but in times of tradegy is morally not right. Yes I'm from the Philippines and I'm not saying this against China. Many people here don't get it, it isn't like China and the Philippines are at war and we are each other's enemies. We are a small country with a backward state of everything including our military. Of all the world China knows these and siezed every oppurtunity to creep in our zone in South China sea. We have no military assests to matach so mostly use our voice and the diplomatic channels. As you might guess, my opinion is that humans (all cultures of the world) have equal tendency to create the idea of an "other" who can be vilified to their own benefit.

Money speaks, and coddles, and corrupts, and buys influence where none should exist...if we were a saner society. Remember the dictum 'first come first serve'? Now we have reservations for just about anything but even that is no guarantee that we will be included, as there may always be exceptions to the rule. Besides, we live in exceptional times, thus requiring exceptions that benefit the well connected, perfectly understandable for those sophisticated enough to belong. This phenomenon is becoming universal, a privilege of those at the top, supposedly not to be messed with. Ideally, if one could stop participating or contributing and accepting a corrupt and unequal system, a change may be forthcoming; but more likely than not, one would be left out in the cold.

I've already seen that. The military had a private world wide telephone system. Calls were ranked by the caller in priorities of Routine, Priority, Flash and Flash Override. A higher priority call could bump the lower rated caller from his call so making calls in Flash Override became very routine.
We used to monitor calls occasionally. Would anyone be surprised to know that many of them going to the DC area were made by Admirals and Generals to area golf courses to set up tee times?
A Flash Override call could only be knocked down manually by myself the technician. On occasion I had to do that to allow a real military situation call to go through. And then would come the complaints about how the Admirals calls were being cut off.

So you believe in punishing Israeli universities for the actions of the Israeli Government?  I don't want to be blamed for the recent stupid wars our government has fought.

Many of us would support a general international boycott to force Israel out of other people's land. We are precluded from doing this by our own captive government. Hence an academic boycott, while regrettable, appears to be the only game in town for the ethically inclined.

Academic freedom is now mostly an illusion at American institutions.  It may exist in theory, but the workforce has been so bludgeoned by budget cuts and the adjunctification of the academy that it scarcely exists in reality.  In today's corporate university, people just keep their heads down and try to keep their jobs.  Professor Fish is discussing a principle that only touches a tiny segment of the academy.  Given that universities are now basically corporations, how is this boycott any different than attempts to boycott Walmart or Chick-fil-A in response to the vile policies of management?  I personally don't think such boycotts are particularly effective and tend to hurt the wrong people, but I do think people and organizations have the right to refuse to do business with companies they consider bigoted or exploitative.  I propose that Israeli universities be held to the same standards as Chick-fil-A.  They've earned at least that much.

I think you misread De Tockqueville. As I recall, he didn't say that American was a middle-class society. Rather, he said that in America, people uniquely desire to appear middle-class. There's a big difference.

De Tocqueville's vigorous egalitarian democracy has been long dead as the fundamental realities of America have become class stratification and extreme poverty. Political democracy is itself so endangered by voter restrictions that not ever former Speaker Jim Wright could get Texas voter ID despite having spent 34 years in Congress as a rep from Texas. In the recent Virginia election a third of the seats were won by acclamation: in real democracies major parties contest every seat.

There's zero Upstairs Downstairs or Downton Abbey about the new American overclass; instead of class there's crass. Brit stratification, which is now far less than American class division, was based on an archaic noblesse oblige, a sense of community that humanized the class distinctions. In the U.S., it appears as just vulgarity, an eagerness to spend for the purpose of proving oneself better. The American rich live in private enclaves on private roads going to private schools, using private parks and private airplanes, rarely encountering people who aren't rich. Even Democratic leaders live in bubbles. No radical chic and mau-mauing the flak catchers.

At the other end of the spectrum are the one-fourth of American children growing up in Third World poverty. I once raised funds for a food bank, and all the charitable giving goes to elite health and cultural institutions. People in actual need benefit little from largess whose major function is benefiting the profile and networking of the rich.

You are actually complaining about AirTran, one of the steepest discount airlines out there?

You probably bought the ticket because of the low price. And yet you expect the overworked and underpaid flight attendants to bow down to your every whim.

Who is the elitist here?
We are falling for it.  The airlines are profitable now, for the first time in a long while, and it is entirely because of the extra charges for bags, etc....

In response to Mr. Binion, I did not buy the ticket on AirTran because of the price. It was, in fact, close to the price of other airlines to where I was going, but they had what I thought was clearer policy with regard to carrying sporting equipment as checked baggage. "Bow(ing) down to every whim" is the last thing anyone expects on any airline these days. Nothing in my comment indicated the expectation of anything like that.

I am also acutely aware that virtually all of the airline attendants are underpaid and overworked. AirTran is the rudest I have ever encountered anywhere at any time, including flying in the weeks right after 9-11, 2001. It seemed to me that the people at AirTran, from the ticket counter to the aircraft were looking for opportunities to disrespect or ignore the needs of the passenger.

British Air, in business a lot longer and obviously more professional, is an example of an airline that is firm in its directions to passengers. The attendants there let you know that they are in charge and they expect compliance with their instructions, but they do so without being insulting.

There is a fairly simple rule for business conduct, whether on an airline or in other fields. If the price set by the business is 1 dollar or 10,000 dollars, the purchaser is entitled to decent, respectful treatment and full value for the service they purchased. The "value" is defined by the terms on which a product or service is offered. Not so complicated.

There already is currently rank for use the restrooms on aircraft.

One is consistently discouraged from moving forward and using that facility, even if the way to the back of the aircraft is blocked. On longer flights with business class, the airline attendants carefully patrol the use restrooms in those sections. Once, I watched half a dozen people go forward to use the business class restroom. When I took my first four steps in that direction, I was called down immediately. No one knows what the rules are and they can be changed by whim of the attendant.

I have about half a million miles on commercial aircraft, so I like to think I know how to behave myself and be polite. This matters not at all. To the flight attendants, I am just another problem. The attendants on AirTran seem to be the worst, waiting for the moment they can tell the passenger that he or she is doing something wrong. The TSA has rules against "congregating" near the forward restroom, but is one person a congregation? To AirTran, the answer is apparently yes.

It seems the American airlines industry has lost its way and they want to blame it all on the passenger. Charging for every little upgrade is a business plan made by fools and made worse by over management every step of the way. This is not symptomatic of a society seeking differentiation, but of a business mentality seeking to "monetize" every moment of human life. If we fall for this shell game, it is our fault.

My Uncle and I were stationed once at the same Naval Base. In public I saluted him and called him Sir. It was an honor he'd earned. My two Great Uncles seved on the same ship 1914 to 1918 on a Far East cruise. One was a Chief Petty Officer and the other a Commissioned Officer. As an enlisted man I am sure they never ate dinner together in the Ward Room as was the case with my Uncle and I. Rank does have its privileges as well as its responsibilities.
They've provided us a chain of venues in which we can see extraterrestrials 24/7, with no queue, A-list or optional frills. Once the zoos take up tiered pricing, how far behind can Walmart be?

I don't like class distinctions. My father was a Scottish immigrant who spent 14 years in the West Virginia coal mines. We were solidly lower working class. But I gained a modest NY State Regents scholarship thanks to a statewide competitive exam. I commuted to a not well known university to gain a degree in engineering and an ROTC commission in the Air Force. In 1958, every healthy male was going to serve in the military. So I became an officer. My uncle Bill was stationed in Honolulu in when Pearl Harbor was attacked. He was an enlisted man. At the time, I was a 5 year old in kindergarten. We were both on active duty at the same time, he a senior NCO, I a junior officer. Would I expect him to call me Sir? Never in a million years.

A few years later, I had a senior NCO join my unit. When I welcomed him, I noticed he wore pilot wings. He explained he had been a B-17 pilot who flew 25 perilous missions over Germany. As a young captain, I was in awe,

We must, for our survival, re-establish an egalitarian society. What have the Walmart family, with its 150 billion dollars, done for America, other than weakened it with Chinese trash?
